title: There Ain’t No Party Like a Brexit Party Cuz a Brexit Party Is Quite Hard to Pin Down
text:
LONDON—Britons divided over whether the U.K. should leave the European Union are finding common ground on one thing. The occasion deserves to be marked by a party.

But how can you plan a national send-off if no one knows for sure when it’s going to happen?

Brexit party planners have been burned before. So far, the British government has renegotiated its deadline with the EU twice, moving it from March to April, then to Oct. 31. Party planning revved up. Then Parliament wrested control of the process from Prime Minister Boris Johnson, ordering him to delay Brexit unless he hashes out an arrangement with the EU.

Undeterred, Growlers & Cans, a pub southwest of London in Guildford, slapped a warning on its Oct. 31 Halloween/Brexit party invitation: “Disclaimer: Growlers & Cans by no means guarantees Brexit will have actually happened by this date!”

Event organizer Charlie Martin said the pub is stocking up on Italian and German beer in preparation for the bash.

The King’s Head plans to hand out Boris Johnson masks at its party. Photo: Lauren Almeida/The Wall Street Journal

LondonSwedes, a U.K.-based group of Swedish expatriates, has tried to host a “U.K.’s Leaving Drinks” twice before, with more than 17,000 people registered as interested on its Facebook page. Both nights were thwarted by government delays.

“People lost trust in the U.K. and in the event,” said Charlotte Ågren, the group’s founder, who won’t be organizing a third party for October.

The Old Nun’s Head pub in London planned a “U.K. Leaving Drinks” back on March 29. When the U.K. pushed back that deadline, the pub didn’t follow suit.

“We promised a Brexit party, so we delivered what the government couldn’t,” said pub manager Nick McNeill. A DJ played European music for four hours, including lots of ABBA, a group that hailed from EU member Sweden.

The Old Nun's Head went ahead with a Brexit party in March even though the government pushed back the deadline. Photo: Nick McNeill

The U.K. didn’t leave anywhere that day, so the turnout was disappointing. “We’re not sure if we’ll host another one,” said Mr. McNeill. “We’re undecided, because we’ve been burned in the past.”

Other planners are convinced the Oct. 31 deadline is different.

“This time feels a bit more certain, although we still don’t know what Brexit will look like,” said Virginie Clerk, the organizer of London cabaret show Soiree Pompette. She has scheduled a special performance for Oct. 31 called Brexit: Encore Une Fois!, or Brexit: Once Again!

“We were poised for the deadline in March. We had a countdown on the night before—it was meant to be like the last days of Rome,” recalled Ms. Clerk. “If it is delayed again, we will keep going. It just adds to the absurdity. There’s something absurd about our cabaret, and there’s something bloody silly about Brexit.”

Share Your Thoughts Would you attend a party for a major geopolitical event? Join the conversation below.

The King’s Head, a pub in the southeastern England town of Deal that has been in business since the mid-1600s, is more confident in the government’s promise to deliver by Halloween. The pub, which has a newspaper clipping on the wall about a visit from Brexit Party leader Nigel Farage, plans to hold “Boris’s Big Brexit Bash” on Nov. 1.

The pub intends to hand out Boris Johnson masks and serve a free shot to any patron who comes dressed as the prime minister, presumably in a rumpled suit with tousled hair. “We’re real Boris fans,” said Jamie Cavell, the pub’s manager.

Brexit Party leader Nigel Farage, center, stopped at the King’s Head when he visited Deal. Photo: Jamie Cavell

“He is a maverick who is standing up for the electorate,” said Daniel Underwood, a regular.

Across the North Sea, the Dutch are putting together a beach party to wave goodbye to the U.K. “We understand that they’re leaving on their own adventure, a trip that we do not dare to take, or we do not want to take,” said Ron Toekook, the organizer of Brexit aan Zee, or Brexit at Sea.

The British will wave right back from a Brexit-day party on their own shores.

“It was the Dutch’s idea first. And I thought: whatever they can do, we can do better,” said Stu Cohen, who is organizing a beach party in Norfolk, a region in England that voted “leave.” He plans to mark the occasion with fireworks and fish and chips.

“If it doesn’t happen, we’ll do another one until it does,” said Mr. Cohen.

Members of Leavers of Britain, a network of pro-Brexit voters, are holding off until they feel more confident in the government’s ability to deliver on Halloween.

Old Nun’s Head pub in London is undecided about whether to hold another Brexit party. Photo: Nick McNeill

“We’re used to having to organize things with fairly short notice,” said Paul Hepden, a volunteer coordinator at the Leavers of Bristol group.

The governing Conservative Party maintains Brexit will happen on Oct. 31 despite it losing its parliamentary majority. The government noted in September that only half of the population believed Brexit would actually happen by Halloween.

Some party planners remain steadfast. The Conservatives of the Arundel and South Downs constituency north of London will host “The Great British Brexit Celebration” on Nov. 1. Tickets are nonrefundable.
description: Those planning for the big national send-off don’t know for sure when it’s going to happen; ‘we’ve been burned in the past.’
